There was no moral to the proceedings at the Assembly last
Thursday. The first speaker was
"Jack" Scherr, who talked very eloquently through his saxophone.
And it was with a great deal of surprise and pleasure that the student
body received the announcement
from Thomas Magill that a musical
program would be offered instead
of the usual address.
Scherr played "Saxophobia" and
"Mighty Lak' a Rose" with his
usual skill and apparent lack of effort, assisted by the inimitable
Steinwald at the piano. Jack also
handled two saxophones at once as
if he had been doing it all his life,
and received as much applause for
his sang froid as for the stunt itself.
Syncopation Exhibition by Rogers
PP

Formal announcements have been
issued by the Tudor and Stuart
Club, a Johns Hopkins literary circle which has already contributed
several illuminating lectures on the
literature of the period which gives
the organization its name, of a lecture to be given in the C. E. Hall
on January 16 by Professor Edwin
Greenlaw, Dean of the Graduate
School of the University of North
Carolina. Professor Greenlaw will
discuss English Literature and the
New Science in the Seventeenth
Century." The address, which will
be at five P. M., Friday evening,
will be open to the public and the
undergraduate student body, which,
it is hoped, will manifest a high
degree of interest.
Ph. D. Received at Harvard

Professor Greenlaw, who was
born at Flora, Illinois, in 1874, received his A. B. degree from Northwestern University in 1897, and a
year later he received an A. M. He
afterwards attended Harvard where
he obtained A. M. and Ph. D. degrees. Taking up the profession
of teaching, he entered upon that
career which has placed him, for
the present, in the position of dean
of the North Carolina institution.
He chose his.alma mater, the Northwestern University, for his first experience as an instructor in English. At the University of Chicago
from 1904 to 1907, at Harvard in
1910-11, and at Adelphi College,
Brooklyn, N. Y., he pursued his
chosen profession. In 1913 he became a professor of English and
in 1918 he accepted the office which
he now holds as Dean of the Graduate School of the University of
North Carolina. Extra experience
at Columbia, Leland Stanford and
Harvard has enabled Professor
Greenlaw to rank among the leading educators of the country.

PROFESSOR VINCENT
TO RETIRE THIS YEAR
Professor J. M. Vincent
at the end of the present
academic year will resign his
professorship of European
History and retire from active duty at the university.
After an uninterrupted service of thirty-three years as
a member of the faculty he
will be free to pursue other
literary occupations.
Dr. Vincent came to the
university as a student after two years' study in Germany and received his Ph.
D. in 1890. While again absent in Europe he was called
back as an Associate in History in 1892 and promoted
to the full professorship in
1905.
He expects to remain a citizen of Baltimore and will
continue historical investigation. He hopes to complete for publication certain
studies in European history
upon which he has been for
years collecting materials.

With a small cast and numerous
rehearsals the Homewood Playshop
has been actively engaged in preparing for its January bill, which will
be a three-act play, "The House Into Which We Are Born" (La Maison Natale), by Jacques Copean.
The five performances scheduled
will be put on at the Campus Theater on the evenings of January 15,
16, 17, 20, and 21.
Dr. Small, President of the Playshop, predicted that "The House
Into Which We Are Born" will be
received with great favor in Baltimore. The play, he said, successfully held the stage of the Vieux
Colombier, the most prominent Little Theater in Paris, all last season.
Jacques Copean has been director
of the Vieux Colombier for the past
twenty years, and this play is the
fruit of his long experience. The
Playshop production will be the
first in America.

Practice Resumed After Exams

Practice has been suspended
until after the mid-year examinations. After that time, however,
regular work and training will
begin, and practice will be held
Tuesday,
Wednesday,
every
Thursday, Friday and Saturday
afternoons. All men who can or
think they might be able to play
lacrosse are urged to try out immediately after examinations.
Candidates for manager will report to Manager John Tull Baker.
The Red Eagle team will be
abandoned this year, but a freshman twelve will take its place.
Paul Bachman, last year's point,
has volunteered to coach the team
A regular schedule will be filled
out with City College, Polytechnic, L'Hirondelle Club, and probably Maryland Freshmen and
Navy Plebes as opponents. All
Freshmen who are not members
of the varsity squad will be eligible.

PRICE 5 CENTS

Tag Day will again make its
appearance on the campus. The
first Tag Day of the term will be
Thursday, January 15, on which
day from morning until night,
tags will be sold. In resorting to
this method of soliciting the financial support of Johns Hopkins
students, the 1925 June Week
Committee is following the examples set by similar committees
of '23 and '2_4. Every undergraduate is expected to purchase one
or more of these tags which will
be in the hands of the Committee
and a number of other men. Because the drawing did not produce
the expected financial results, the
June Week Committee has deemed it advisable to employ the Tag
Day method which, in previous
years, has done much to defray
June Week expenses. January 15
will be the first of a series of Tag
Days to be held until the culmination of preparations, June
Week.
Plans Progressing Rapidly

That some important announcements will soon be forthcoming
was indicated by W. C. Gardner,
chairman of the 1925 June Week
Committee. Work is progressing
rapidly on the plans for the June
Week festivities which, according
to the chairman, will be extensive
and elaborate. Announcements
in regard to the entertainments
will be made in the near. future.
Within the next,dew weeks a
contract will be signed with one
of the leading orchestras of the
country. No definite decision .in
regard to the choice of orchestra
has yet been made, as several of
the most prominent are under
consideration with the idea of ,engaging one of them for several
days.
To do away with any possible
misunderstanding in the lower
classes, the 1925 June Week
Committee announces that the
festivities next spring will be for
the enjoyment of not only the
seniors, but of the entire undergraduate body, and for this reason
it is considered each man's duty

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 13, 1925
TRADITION
Lack of tradition has many times been pointed out as •one of
the chief defects of Johns Hopkins. Some have gone so far as to
attribute seeming lack of spirit to the existence of this condition.
This, of course, may or may not be true. Nevertheless, it is logical
'to suppose that a certain feeling of reverence and inspiration among
the Alumni would be enlivened if they could see in the University
of the present, the customs which they recall from their own college
days. A custom which has been in force for a long time naturally
acquires respect, and the greater the age the more respect it will
acquire, since man believes quite properly, that wrong will not persist for ages.
Johns Hopkins is young, it is true. But this excuse has been
overworked. For a university which has been in existence for nearly
a half century and which commands a towering position among institutions of advanced learning, there is little reason why tradition
should be conspicuous by its absence. Even though undergraduate
Hopkins has not been emphasized, it has not been neglected. Yet,
In the establishment of tradition there are criteria of judgment which
should be applied, lest custom becomes merely a useless survival of
primitive times. Even the most venerable tradition should be able
to bear the pragmatic test, "Will it work?" Two standards applicable to custom are those of expediency and of common sense. If the
tradition will correlate with the life, habits, and conditions of the
present and serve the purpose for which it is founded, if it is the outgrowth of some demand, the answer to some need in college life, it is
'amply justified.
The News-Letter withholds its opinion of the traditions of parades and bonfires before important games, the attempt of the Musical Club to establish the custom of having its annual home concert
the evening before or the evening of Commemoration Day, and
others. However, the value of tradition, if it passes the tests, is
enormous and efforts towards establishment of tradition should be
encouraged. In order that traditional dates may be kept free from
confliction, the News-Letter offers the following suggestion for consideration of the University authorities.
A CAMPUS CALENDAR
Maintenance of a campus calendar sems warranted by a repeated
occurrence of conflicting dates. Instances of this nature, luckily,
'nave been few. Yet, one case in particular has attracted campus attention, the scheduling .of the annual home concert of the Musical
'Club and the Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Games for February 23rd.
Last year a similar tie-up was experienced which resulted in the Musical Club changing three times the date set for its performance. The
(managers of the Musical Club, recalling the unpleasant entanglement
last year, endeavored to avoid a repetition of it by consulting the athletic authorities early in the fall. At the time, this date being open
to both parties, the concert was booked for February 23rd. Then the
indoor meet was scheduled for the same date. To the outside world
a condition of this kind would naturally indicate internal friction between campus activities. Hence, would it not be wise to adopt a
campus calendar and compel every activity to obtain permission for
dates? In order that it may be effective, the calendar would have
to be maintained by the faculty, since the faculty alone exercises authority over all activities, both athletic and non-athletic.

SCHOLASTIC SUCCESS
Continued from page 1

case is purely mechanical and in
all probability he fails the course.
The secret of success in college is to develop an interest and
curiosity in one's studies. The
student should do a great deal of
outside reading, particularly in
his "major", 'which should become his hobby. Although text
book assignments represent the
minimum work required, the
student must usually be driven to
accomplish that much. Because
of this attitude of the student
body towards courses of study,
the instructors find it necessary
to give tests and examinations.
As an illustration of what interest in a subject can accomplish
Dr. Mitchell told of a young man
who, having reached college after
great scholastic difficulty, was
failing because he looked upon
study as a very disagreeable task.
Through chance this fellow became interested in bees, and began to keep them for honey. He
was so absorbed in bee keeping
that he was transferred to an agricultural college to study the
subject. When the war broke
out, he took his text books to
France and studied in the trenches. He came back severely injured, but continued to study and
received his degree. Now he is
one of the most prosperous bee
keepers in the country.
Dr. Mitchell said that most college undergraduates take in the
lectures by their instructors in
much the same way as fledgelings receive pre-digested food

from the mother bird. The way
in which to get the greatest benefit from college study is to get
the information for oneself, to
learn to separate the true from
the false without depending upon
an instructor.

and even electrical engineers

electrical industry
Nowadays the electrical industry needs so
many types of men that it may be well to
point out it still needs engineers, good engineers—but with a difference.
Vision, initiative, technical skill are needed
qualities, now as always. But here's another.
Can you work on the team? Will you be
able to back up the other members in the
manufacturing and commercial ends of the
business?
The engineer today should be no recluse
in a laboratory. He can make his work more
effective once he sees how it relates to the
work of men around him.
In your studies and college activities, you
have the chance now to develop this point
of view. In the broader activities of the
electrical industry, you may have the chance
later on to carry it further.

There was no moral to the proceedings at the Assembly last
Thursday. The first speaker was
"Jack" Scherr, who talked very eloquently through his saxophone.
And it was with a great deal of surprise and pleasure that the student
body received the announcement
from Thomas Magill that a musical
program would be offered instead
of the usual address.
Scherr played "Saxophobia" and
"Mighty Lak' a Rose" with his
usual skill and apparent lack of effort, assisted by the inimitable
Steinwald at the piano. Jack also
handled two saxophones at once as
if he had been doing it all his life,
and received as much applause for
his sang froid as for the stunt itself.
Syncopation Exhibition by Rogers
PP

Formal announcements have been
issued by the Tudor and Stuart
Club, a Johns Hopkins literary circle which has already contributed
several illuminating lectures on the
literature of the period which gives
the organization its name, of a lecture to be given in the C. E. Hall
on January 16 by Professor Edwin
Greenlaw, Dean of the Graduate
School of the University of North
Carolina. Professor Greenlaw will
discuss English Literature and the
New Science in the Seventeenth
Century." The address, which will
be at five P. M., Friday evening,
will be open to the public and the
undergraduate student body, which,
it is hoped, will manifest a high
degree of interest.
Ph. D. Received at Harvard

Professor Greenlaw, who was
born at Flora, Illinois, in 1874, received his A. B. degree from Northwestern University in 1897, and a
year later he received an A. M. He
afterwards attended Harvard where
he obtained A. M. and Ph. D. degrees. Taking up the profession
of teaching, he entered upon that
career which has placed him, for
the present, in the position of dean
of the North Carolina institution.
He chose his.alma mater, the Northwestern University, for his first experience as an instructor in English. At the University of Chicago
from 1904 to 1907, at Harvard in
1910-11, and at Adelphi College,
Brooklyn, N. Y., he pursued his
chosen profession. In 1913 he became a professor of English and
in 1918 he accepted the office which
he now holds as Dean of the Graduate School of the University of
North Carolina. Extra experience
at Columbia, Leland Stanford and
Harvard has enabled Professor
Greenlaw to rank among the leading educators of the country.

PROFESSOR VINCENT
TO RETIRE THIS YEAR
Professor J. M. Vincent
at the end of the present
academic year will resign his
professorship of European
History and retire from active duty at the university.
After an uninterrupted service of thirty-three years as
a member of the faculty he
will be free to pursue other
literary occupations.
Dr. Vincent came to the
university as a student after two years' study in Germany and received his Ph.
D. in 1890. While again absent in Europe he was called
back as an Associate in History in 1892 and promoted
to the full professorship in
1905.
He expects to remain a citizen of Baltimore and will
continue historical investigation. He hopes to complete for publication certain
studies in European history
upon which he has been for
years collecting materials.

With a small cast and numerous
rehearsals the Homewood Playshop
has been actively engaged in preparing for its January bill, which will
be a three-act play, "The House Into Which We Are Born" (La Maison Natale), by Jacques Copean.
The five performances scheduled
will be put on at the Campus Theater on the evenings of January 15,
16, 17, 20, and 21.
Dr. Small, President of the Playshop, predicted that "The House
Into Which We Are Born" will be
received with great favor in Baltimore. The play, he said, successfully held the stage of the Vieux
Colombier, the most prominent Little Theater in Paris, all last season.
Jacques Copean has been director
of the Vieux Colombier for the past
twenty years, and this play is the
fruit of his long experience. The
Playshop production will be the
first in America.

Practice Resumed After Exams

Practice has been suspended
until after the mid-year examinations. After that time, however,
regular work and training will
begin, and practice will be held
Tuesday,
Wednesday,
every
Thursday, Friday and Saturday
afternoons. All men who can or
think they might be able to play
lacrosse are urged to try out immediately after examinations.
Candidates for manager will report to Manager John Tull Baker.
The Red Eagle team will be
abandoned this year, but a freshman twelve will take its place.
Paul Bachman, last year's point,
has volunteered to coach the team
A regular schedule will be filled
out with City College, Polytechnic, L'Hirondelle Club, and probably Maryland Freshmen and

PRICE 5 CENTS

Tag Day will again make its
appearance on the campus. The
first Tag Day of the term will be
Thursday, January 15, on which
day from morning until night,
tags will be sold. In resorting to
this method of soliciting the financial support of Johns Hopkins
students, the 1925 June Week
Committee is following the examples set by similar committees
of '23 and '2_4. Every undergraduate is expected to purchase one
or more of these tags which will
be in the hands of the Committee
and a number of other men. Because the drawing did not produce
the expected financial results, the
June Week Committee has deemed it advisable to employ the Tag
Day method which, in previous
years, has done much to defray
June Week expenses. January 15
will be the first of a series of Tag
Days to be held until the culmination of preparations, June
Week.
Plans Progressing Rapidly

That some important announcements will soon be forthcoming
was indicated by W. C. Gardner,
chairman of the 1925 June Week
Committee. Work is progressing
rapidly on the plans for the June
Week festivities which, according
to the chairman, will be extensive
and elaborate. Announcements
in regard to the entertainments
will be made in the near. future.
Within the next,dew weeks a
contract will be signed with one
of the leading orchestras of the
country. No definite decision .in
regard to the choice of orchestra
has yet been made, as several of
the most prominent are under
consideration with the idea of ,engaging one of them for several
days.
To do away with any possible
misunderstanding in the lower
classes, the 1925 June Week
Committee announces that the
festivities next spring will be for
the enjoyment of not only the
seniors, but of the entire undergraduate body, and for this reason
it is considered each man's duty

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 13, 1925
TRADITION
Lack of tradition has many times been pointed out as •one of
the chief defects of Johns Hopkins. Some have gone so far as to
attribute seeming lack of spirit to the existence of this condition.
This, of course, may or may not be true. Nevertheless, it is logical
'to suppose that a certain feeling of reverence and inspiration among
the Alumni would be enlivened if they could see in the University
of the present, the customs which they recall from their own college
days. A custom which has been in force for a long time naturally
acquires respect, and the greater the age the more respect it will
acquire, since man believes quite properly, that wrong will not persist for ages.
Johns Hopkins is young, it is true. But this excuse has been
overworked. For a university which has been in existence for nearly
a half century and which commands a towering position among institutions of advanced learning, there is little reason why tradition
should be conspicuous by its absence. Even though undergraduate
Hopkins has not been emphasized, it has not been neglected. Yet,
In the establishment of tradition there are criteria of judgment which
should be applied, lest custom becomes merely a useless survival of
primitive times. Even the most venerable tradition should be able
to bear the pragmatic test, "Will it work?" Two standards applicable to custom are those of expediency and of common sense. If the
tradition will correlate with the life, habits, and conditions of the
present and serve the purpose for which it is founded, if it is the outgrowth of some demand, the answer to some need in college life, it is
'amply justified.
The News-Letter withholds its opinion of the traditions of parades and bonfires before important games, the attempt of the Musical Club to establish the custom of having its annual home concert
the evening before or the evening of Commemoration Day, and
others. However, the value of tradition, if it passes the tests, is
enormous and efforts towards establishment of tradition should be
encouraged. In order that traditional dates may be kept free from
confliction, the News-Letter offers the following suggestion for consideration of the University authorities.
A CAMPUS CALENDAR
Maintenance of a campus calendar sems warranted by a repeated
occurrence of conflicting dates. Instances of this nature, luckily,
'nave been few. Yet, one case in particular has attracted campus attention, the scheduling .of the annual home concert of the Musical
'Club and the Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Games for February 23rd.
Last year a similar tie-up was experienced which resulted in the Musical Club changing three times the date set for its performance. The
(managers of the Musical Club, recalling the unpleasant entanglement
last year, endeavored to avoid a repetition of it by consulting the athletic authorities early in the fall. At the time, this date being open
to both parties, the concert was booked for February 23rd. Then the
indoor meet was scheduled for the same date. To the outside world
a condition of this kind would naturally indicate internal friction between campus activities. Hence, would it not be wise to adopt a
campus calendar and compel every activity to obtain permission for
dates? In order that it may be effective, the calendar would have
to be maintained by the faculty, since the faculty alone exercises authority over all activities, both athletic and non-athletic.

case is purely mechanical and in

The secret of success in college is to develop an interest and
curiosity in one's studies. The
student should do a great deal of
outside reading, particularly in
his "major", 'which should become his hobby. Although text
book assignments represent the
minimum work required, the
student must usually be driven to
accomplish that much. Because
of this attitude of the student
body towards courses of study,
the instructors find it necessary
to give tests and examinations.
As an illustration of what interest in a subject can accomplish
Dr. Mitchell told of a young man
who, having reached college after
great scholastic difficulty, was
failing because he looked upon
study as a very disagreeable task.
Through chance this fellow became interested in bees, and began to keep them for honey. He
was so absorbed in bee keeping
that he was transferred to an agricultural college to study the
subject. When the war broke
out, he took his text books to
France and studied in the trenches. He came back severely injured, but continued to study and
received his degree. Now he is
one of the most prosperous bee
keepers in the country.
Dr. Mitchell said that most college undergraduates take in the
lectures by their instructors in
much the same way as fledgelings receive pre-digested food

from the mother bird. The way
in which to get the greatest benefit from college study is to get
the information for oneself, to
learn to separate the true from
the false without depending upon
an instructor.

and even electrical engineers

Nowadays the electrical industry needs so
many types of men that it may be well to
point out it still needs engineers, good engineers—but with a difference.
Vision, initiative, technical skill are needed
qualities, now as always. But here's another.
Can you work on the team? Will you be
able to back up the other members in the
manufacturing and commercial ends of the
business?
The engineer today should be no recluse
in a laboratory. He can make his work more
effective once he sees how it relates to the
work of men around him.
